If even the investors who focus on super-fast growing startups don’t see the big picture, it’s no wonder that most people miss it too. Power law distributions are so huge that they can be hard to notice. For example, when people outside of Silicon Valley think about venture capital, they might imagine a small, quirky group like the show Shark Tank, but without the ads. 

In reality, less than 1% of new businesses started each year in the U.S. get venture funding, and total venture capital investment is only about 0.2% of the country’s economy. But the companies that do get this funding have a huge impact on the economy. Venture-backed businesses create 11% of all private sector jobs and bring in yearly revenues that make up about 21% of the GDP. In fact, the twelve biggest tech companies all received venture backing, and together, they are worth over $2 trillion, which is more than all other tech companies put together.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Venture capital is a small part of the economy, but it helps create a lot of jobs and revenue. The biggest tech companies are backed by venture funding, showing its huge impact.
